awd_titl_txt: University of Alaska Fairbanks/Sikuliaq Shipboard Scientific Equipment (SSSE) - 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Summary	
								
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the Academic Research Fleet (ARF) fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. UAF requests funds to purchase and install Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment that would enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2020, during the pandemic-shortened season, Sikuliaq completed 134 days 124 (93%) of which were for NSF. In 2021, the vessel is scheduled to sail 220 days with 124 (56%) days of the schedule for NSF.  With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment.	
	
1)	Electro-Optical Slip Ring Assembly	$24,972	

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Electro-optical slip ring & winch housing

When Sikuliaq was built, none of the winches were capable of using fiber optic cables. In 2019, we converted one of the two storage drums for the traction winch to be able to run .681 Power Optic cable, which we installed 10 km of in 2020. This gave us a large-diameter strong, heavy cable option, but we’ve also had a need for a smaller, lighter electro-optical tow cable on the hydrographic winch. In order to support this, first the winch – being rotating machinery – must have a slip ring assembly that contains a fiber optic rotary joint (FORJ). The design requirements for this installation called for a small slip ring mounted to the outside of the winch drum at the stub shaft bearing. We ordered two custom assemblies consisting of a 3-pass Princetel FORJ integrated with a 4-contact Alpha slip ring, to take full advantage of .322 electro-optical cable construction. We contracted a mechanical engineer – Dan Markovic – to design and manufacture a housing that mounts to the side of the winch so the slip ring assembly can be installed and protected. The housing also allows for a smaller Meridian MXO-4 slip ring to be installed, which is used on the CTD winch.

In December 2021, we installed the new slip ring and housing while the ship was laid up. We also put together rotating and fixed junction boxes with terminals and fiber optic ST patch panels. Multi-fiber cables were run from the FWD winch room to the Computer Lab, where there is a rack-mounted patch panel for users to jack their equipment into. As part of this upgrade project, we also added a winch control station and three permanently-mounted monitors in the Computer Lab to support tow vehicle operations.

In January 2022, we had SIO’s Markey spooler onsite at the Vigor Portland shipyard for a week. The top priority was to remove 8 km of .322 EM cable from the hydrographic winch, the last of the original conducting cables from the build. We then spooled on a new 5 km length of .322 EO cable ordered by the UNOLS Wire Pool. It has already been used extensively on two different science cruises in the first half of 2022 to support fiber-optic tow vehicles, mitigating the need for a specialized portable winch. Bringing this capability to Sikuliaq has certainly added on further to the responsibilities of the marine technicians, and demands a more complex skillset. But so far the MarTechs have done a great job in implementing these new tools on Sikuliaq, in turn expanding the science capabilities of the vessel and presenting new opportunities for conducting innovative oceanographic research.


Last Modified: 05/20/2022
Modified by: Ethan H Roth
